GetBiggestComp.Comment: @abbr`Determines the biggest component (X, Y, Z, W)`.    The result is the index of the biggest component which can be used with @bold`Coord`@br    @code` s:= v.Coord[ v.GetBiggestComp ]; `@br

Invert.Comment: @abbr`Negates the current vector without altering it`.    The result is only returned without altering the original vector.    This is exivalent to @code`v2:= -v;``@br

length.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the length of the current vector`.@br

length_sq.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the squared length of the current vector`. This is faster than GetDist as it does not calculate the square root.@br

length_manh.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the manhattan length of the current vector`. It is calculated by summing all the fields of the vector.@br

normalize.Comment: @abbr`Normalizes the current vector`.    The vector will be returned in the function's result additionally.    @br@br    For returning a normalized vector without    changing the current one use the @link`p3dMath.normalize` function@br

dot.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the dot product of the current vector and v`.@br

GetBiggestComp.Comment: @abbr`Determines the biggest component (X, Y, Z, W)`.    The result is the index of the biggest component which can be used with @bold`Coord`@br    @code` s:= v.Coord[ v.GetBiggestComp ]; `@br

Invert.Comment: @abbr`Negates the current vector without altering it`.    The result is only returned without altering the original vector.    This is exivalent to @code`v2:= -v;``@br

length.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the length of the current vector`.@br

length_sq.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the squared length of the current vector`. This is faster than GetDist as it does not calculate the square root.@br

length_manh.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the manhattan length of the current vector`. It is calculated by summing all the fields of the vector.@br

normalize.Comment: @abbr`Normalizes the current vector`.    The vector will be returned in the function's result additionally.    @br@br    For returning a normalized vector without    changing the current one use the @link`p3dMath.normalize` function@br

cross.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the cross product of the current vector and v`.@br

dot.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the dot product of the current vector and v`.@br

GetBiggestComp.Comment: @abbr`Determines the biggest component (X, Y, Z, W)`.    The result is the index of the biggest component which can be used with @bold`Coord`@br    @code` s:= v.Coord[ v.GetBiggestComp ]; `@br

Invert.Comment: @abbr`Negates the current vector without altering it`.    The result is only returned without altering the original vector.    This is exivalent to @code`v2:= -v;``@br

length.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the length of the current vector`.@br

length_sq.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the squared length of the current vector`. This is faster than GetDist as it does not calculate the square root.@br

length_manh.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the manhattan length of the current vector`. It is calculated by summing all the fields of the vector.@br

normalize.Comment: @abbr`Normalizes the current vector`.    The vector will be returned in the function's result additionally.    @br@br    For returning a normalized vector without    changing the current one use the @link`p3dMath.normalize` function@br

cross.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the cross product of the current vector and v`.@br

dot.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the dot product of the current vector and v`.@br

GetBiggestComp.Comment: @abbr`Determines the biggest component (X, Y, Z, W)`.    The result is the index of the biggest component which can be used with @bold`Coord`@br    @code` s:= v.Coord[ v.GetBiggestComp ]; `@br

Invert.Comment: @abbr`Negates the current vector without altering it`.    The result is only returned without altering the original vector.    This is exivalent to @code`v2:= -v;``@br

length.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the length of the current vector`.@br

length_sq.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the squared length of the current vector`. This is faster than GetDist as it does not calculate the square root.@br

length_manh.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the manhattan length of the current vector`. It is calculated by summing all the fields of the vector.@br

normalize.Comment: @abbr`Normalizes the current vector`.    The vector will be returned in the function's result additionally.    @br@br    For returning a normalized vector without    changing the current one use the @link`p3dMath.normalize` function@br

cross.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the cross product of the current vector and v`.@br

dot.Comment: @abbr`Calculate the dot product of the current vector and v`.@br

normalize.Comment: @abbr`This return a normalized vector leaving the original vector untouched`.@br

dot.Comment: @abbr`This will return the dot product of two vectors`.@br

reflect.Comment: @abbr`Will reflect an input vector using a normal vector.` For a given incident vector I and surface normal N reflect returns the reflection direction calculated as I - 2.0 * dot(N, I) * N.@br N should be normalized in order to achieve the desired result.@br

distance.Comment: @abbr`Returns the distance between the two points p0 and p1`.@br

smoothstep.Comment: @abbr`Will make a gradient between two edges`.@br

floor.Comment: @abbr`Returns a value equal to the nearest integer that is less than or equal to x`.@br

ceil.Comment: @abbr`Returns a value equal to the nearest integer that is greater than or equal to x`.@br

_length.Comment: @abbr`Returns the length of the vector`. It's not called length because it would@br override the function Length from system, which is invisible then.@br

length_sq.Comment: @abbr`Returns the length of the vector`. It's not called length because it would@br override the function Length from system, which is invisible then.@br

max.Comment: @abbr`Will return the bigger components of one vector and a scalar`. It works component-wise.@br

min.Comment: @abbr`Will return the smaller components of one vector and a scalar`. It works component-wise.@br

clamp.Comment: @abbr`Returns the value of x constrained to the range minVal to maxVal`. The returned value is computed as min(max(x, minVal), maxVal).@br

abs.Comment: @abbr`Returns x if x >= 0; otherwise, it returns -x`.@br

mix.Comment: @abbr`Returns the value of x constrained to the range minVal to maxVal`. The returned value is computed as min(max(x, minVal), maxVal).@br

cross.Comment: @abbr`This will return the cross product of two vectors`.@br

mat2.Comment: @abbr`Will create a two by two matrix from a four by four matrix`. The additional rows and columns are truncated.@br

mat4.Comment: @abbr`Will create a four by four matrix from a three by three matrix`.@br The additional row and column are set to 0 except for _33 which is set to 1.@br

mat4perspectiveFOVLH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a left handed perspective 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

mat4perspectiveFOVRH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a right handed perspective 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

mat4orthoRH.Comment: //@abbr`Returns a left handed orthogonal 4 by 4 projection matrix`.function mat4orthoRH( w, h, zNear, zFar: Float ): TMat4;{$IFDEF IMPLEMENTATION}begin  Result._00:= 2/( w );                             Result._01:= 0;                                   Result._02:= 0;                     Result._03:= 0;  Result._10:= 0;                                   Result._11:= 2/( h );                             Result._12:= 0;                     Result._13:= 0;  Result._20:= 0;                                   Result._21:= 0;                                   Result._22:= 2/ ( zFar - zNear );   Result._23:= 0;  Result._30:= 0;                                   Result._31:= 0;                  Result._32:= ( zFar + zNear ) / ( zFar - zNear );    Result._33:= 1;end;{$ENDIF}{>>$WARNINGS OFF} // Omit warnings about the function result variable not being initialized@br @abbr`Returns a right handed orthogonal 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

mat4lookatLH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a left handed 4 by 4 lookat matrix which can be used for cameras`.@br

mat4lookatRH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a right handed 4 by 4 lookat matrix which can be used for cameras`.@br

dmat2.Comment: @abbr`Will create a two by two matrix from a four by four matrix`. The additional rows and columns are truncated.@br

dmat4.Comment: @abbr`Will create a four by four matrix from a three by three matrix`.@br The additional row and column are set to 0 except for _33 which is set to 1.@br

dmat4perspectiveFOVLH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a left handed perspective 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

dmat4perspectiveFOVRH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a right handed perspective 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

dmat4orthoLH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a left handed orthogonal 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

dmat4orthoRH.Comment: //@abbr`Returns a left handed orthogonal 4 by 4 projection matrix`.function dmat4orthoRH( w, h, zNear, zFar: Double ): TDMat4;{$IFDEF IMPLEMENTATION}begin  Result._00:= 2/( w );                             Result._01:= 0;                                   Result._02:= 0;                     Result._03:= 0;  Result._10:= 0;                                   Result._11:= 2/( h );                             Result._12:= 0;                     Result._13:= 0;  Result._20:= 0;                                   Result._21:= 0;                                   Result._22:= 2/ ( zFar - zNear );   Result._23:= 0;  Result._30:= 0;                                   Result._31:= 0;                  Result._32:= ( zFar + zNear ) / ( zFar - zNear );    Result._33:= 1;end;{$ENDIF}{>>$WARNINGS OFF} // Omit warnings about the function result variable not being initialized@br @abbr`Returns a right handed orthogonal 4 by 4 projection matrix`.@br

dmat4lookatLH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a left handed 4 by 4 lookat matrix which can be used for cameras`.@br

dmat4lookatRH.Comment: @abbr`Returns a right handed 4 by 4 lookat matrix which can be used for cameras`.@br

imat2.Comment: @abbr`Will create a two by two matrix from a four by four matrix`. The additional rows and columns are truncated.@br

imat3.Comment: @abbr`Will create a three by three matrix from a two by two matrix`.@br The additional row and column are set to 0 except for _22 which is set to 1.@br

imat4.Comment: @abbr`Will create a four by four matrix from a three by three matrix`.@br The additional row and column are set to 0 except for _33 which is set to 1.@br

epsilon.Comment: Constant used internally to eliminate precision errors.@br

vec2_Axis_PX.Comment: This is a @link( TVec2 ) constant for the positive X-Axis when working with two dimension.@br

vec2_Axis_PY.Comment: This is a @link( TVec2 ) constant for the positive Y-Axis when working with two dimension.@br

vec2_Axis_NX.Comment: This is a @link( TVec2 ) constant for the negative X-Axis when working with two dimension.@br

vec2_Axis_NY.Comment: This is a @link( TVec2 ) constant for the negative Y-Axis when working with two dimension.@br

vec3_Axis_PX.Comment: This is a @link( TVec3 ) constant for the positive X-Axis when working with three dimension.@br

vec3_Axis_PY.Comment: This is a @link( TVec3 ) constant for the positive Y-Axis when working with three dimension.@br

vec3_Axis_PZ.Comment: This is a @link( TVec3 ) constant for the positive Z-Axis when working with three dimension.@br

vec3_Axis_NX.Comment: This is a @link( TVec3 ) constant for the negative X-Axis when working with three dimension.@br

vec3_Axis_NY.Comment: This is a @link( TVec3 ) constant for the negative Y-Axis when working with three dimension.@br

vec3_Axis_NZ.Comment: This is a @link( TVec3 ) constant for the negative Z-Axis when working with three dimension.@br

Mat2Identity.Comment: This is a @link(TMat2) constant for an identity matrix. It is almost equivalent to @link(mat2)( 1 )@br except for the fact that @link(mat2)() calls a function wheras @name is a constant and@br probably faster.@br

Mat3Identity.Comment: This is a @link(TMat3) constant for an identity matrix. It is almost equivalent to @link(mat3)( 1 )@br except for the fact that @link(mat3)() calls a function wheras @name is a constant and@br probably faster.@br

Mat4Identity.Comment: This is a @link(TMat4) constant for an identity matrix. It is almost equivalent to @link(mat4)( 1 )@br except for the fact that @link(mat4)() calls a function wheras @name is a constant and@br probably faster.@br

DMat3Identity.Comment: This is a @link(TMat3) constant for an identity matrix. It is almost equivalent to @link(mat3)( 1 )@br except for the fact that @link(mat3)() calls a function wheras @name is a constant and@br probably faster.@br

DMat4Identity.Comment: This is a @link(TMat4) constant for an identity matrix. It is almost equivalent to @link(mat4)( 1 )@br except for the fact that @link(mat4)() calls a function wheras @name is a constant and@br probably faster.@br
